thread.title: A comeback on Catalina Island
thread.title_full: A comeback on Catalina Island | Dallas Morning News

author: dallasnews
title: A comeback on Catalina Island
text:
Catalina Island, just 22 miles southwest of Los Angeles, is experiencing a big boom in tourism, coinciding with a transformation led by Irvine, Calif.-based Santa Catalina Island Co.
The group, which owns much of the commercial property on the island — including hotels, restaurants and retail areas — has been adding new attractions for the past few years in the hope of drawing more visitors.
The island now boasts a fancy new beach club, a new luxury spa and five consecutive zip lines that start high in the hills near the city of Avalon and soar through Descanso Canyon before ending at the beach two hours later.
Santa Catalina Island Co., or SCICo, owns multiple hotels on the island, including three in Avalon. It also runs restaurants and tourist attractions, and owns virtually all tourist-related enterprises in Catalina’s resort town of Two Harbor.
There are other tourism operators on the island, but SCICo is the largest.
The company was founded by William, Joseph and Hancock Banning, the sons of Phineas Banning — widely known as the father of the Port of Los Angeles — in 1891. William Wrigley Jr., who is best known for chewing gum brands that include Juicy Fruit and Doublemint, and for owning the Chicago Cubs from 1921 until his death 11 years later, bought a controlling interest in SCICo in 1919.
Wrigley spent millions of dollars renovating the island, adding public utilities, a hotel, extensive landscaping and the iconic Catalina Casino.
Today’s modern iteration of the company that Wrigley created is once again building up the island. It has already spent $55 million on projects, and it plans to spend at least $55 million more on other ones, including more island activities such as an aerial adventure park, according to SCICo chief executive Randy Herrel.
Spa
One of the most recent, and biggest, changes to the island was the addition of Island Spa Catalina, which opened in November.
“It’s the first and only resort-style spa on the island. We offer an experience. You can’t get one like this anywhere else,” said spa manager Ashley Seward.
The spa’s nine treatment rooms — including four massage rooms, a couple’s room and two waxing and skin-care rooms — are named after spots on the island such as El Encanto.
Beach Club
Dave Stevenson, SCICo’s vice president of sales and marketing, said the new Descanso Beach Club will attract additional visitors and corporate retreats to the island, which “stretches the season out” beyond the normal Memorial Day-to-Labor Day time period.
The club, which opened in January, has a ballroom that can be divided into two sections and fits 150 to 200 people. It also has a terrace overlooking the ocean and an outdoor gazebo.
Restaurants
Food and restaurants have been a big part of SCICo’s effort to attract more visitors.
Matthew Alleshouse, who started in July as the executive chef of all the company’s restaurants, is focusing on fresh products and favorite island items such as seafood, burgers, wings, ahi tuna salads and fish sandwiches.
“The food is driven from a local standpoint. We do a lot of sustainable products. We work with a lot of farmers,” he said.
Alleshouse is also helming “Catalina’s only made-from-scratch ice cream parlor,” Descanso Fresh. But not all of the ice cream flavors are the ones you remember from growing up.
“We’ve developed quite a few 21 and up ice creams,” he said. Some even have 30 percent alcohol content.
A scoop of ice cream will run you $3.75 and a 16-ounce milkshake will cost $6.50.
One signature flavor is Buffalo Milk, named after the island’s famous Buffalo Milk cocktail.
The drink, a coffee banana milkshake with a kick, can be enjoyed on the beach; Catalina has one of the only public beaches in California where you can drink legally, Stevenson said.
Hotels
SCICo has three hotels in the city of Avalon: the Pavilion Hotel, The Inn on Mt Ada and Hotel Atwater.
Mt Ada is “uber luxe,” Pavilion is a beach boutique hotel, and Atwater is a value hotel, Stevenson said.
The Pavilion, which is in the center of town, has rooms that vary from $155 in the off-season to as much as $950 at peak times, said Roberto Perico, general manager of hotels for the company.
In the summer, occupancy is at 95 percent, and during the winter it is 75 percent to 80 percent full.
Renovations are underway at the roughly 100-room Atwater. The company also sees room for improvement to Catalina’s historic Inn on Mt Ada, which was originally the Wrigley family’s home.
The six-bedroom hotel is so popular that it gets completely booked an entire year in advance.
Stevenson said a second building on the property, which was once staff quarters, will be turned into four to six additional bedrooms.
Drought
Water is an issue on the island. Herrel said the company is using half the water it used in 2012 and 2013, despite a 30 percent increase in business, saving roughly 4.5 million gallons a year.
Restaurants cook with jugs of water. Hotels send laundry to the mainland, ask guests to reuse sheets and towels, and have installed water-efficient showerheads and faucets.
Dishwashers are one of the biggest water guzzlers on the island, but SCICo has plans to use jugs of water for washing dishes, too.
It uses smart water and drip irrigation systems for landscaping, and irrigates the golf course with nonpotable water.
The future
SCICo has more plans. One goal is to add year-round activities that don’t involve the beach.
Herrel wants to energize the casino building to include movies and a film on the island’s history, and to add an aerial adventure park where people can climb on ropes between trees and across the canyon.
There is also a winery on the island that the company wants to open to the public.
Hannah Madans,
Orange County Register
